channel.title: Comments on: Getting remote SQL Service information with Windows Powershell
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Axel Achten (axel8s)
item.dc:creator: Axel Achten (axel8s)
item.description: Thanks for the tip, I changed the code in the post, and of course in my local script;)
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the tip, I changed the code in the post, and of course in my local script;)

item.title: By: Laerte Junior
item.dc:creator: Laerte Junior
item.description: Nice. Just a comment. Always try to use the native parameters in the cmdlet. In this case you can use get-service -name *MSSQL* , avoiding the pipeline streaming to where-object. It is faster and in IMHO, cleaner :)
item.content:encoded: Nice. Just a comment. Always try to use the native parameters in the cmdlet. In this case you can use get-service -name *MSSQL* , avoiding the pipeline streaming to where-object. It is faster and in IMHO, cleaner ðŸ™‚
